name: In Season Criterium - Low Volume - 3:1 w/ Strength
description:
### GOAL  
  
To combine SUF Strength Training and highly specefic and intense structured indoor sessions to train your body for the unique demands of criterium racing, while continuing to race most weekends.  
  
### BEST FOR  
  
- Crit racers who have around 4 hours of time to train each week  
- Crit racers who want to incorporate strength training and regular weekend criterium races, all while building to your target A race on the final day of the plan 2 weeks on, 1 week off Target Race  
  
### TRAINING BLOCKS  
  
### PLAN ENDS WITH  
  
### SPECIAL NOTES  
  
- Each "Optional" Race has another workout listed that day, which is the session you should do if you do not have a race that weekend.  
- This plan is designed specifically to incorporate our SUFSTR training progression. Learn more about our [SUFSTR](https://thesufferfest.com/blogs/training-resources/strength-training-faq?_pos=3&_sid=954a82dae&_ss=r)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: The Cure
prospects.description:
Do you have Couchlandrian Tendencies? This short but powerful workout will cure you of that affliction and reassert your inner Sufferlandrian. The session is based on a combination of specific micro-intervals (made famous by Japanese coach and physiologist Izumi Tabata) that we combined with classic tempo efforts. This gives you a superb mix of Anaerobic Capacity (AC), Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and FTP training stresses in one short workout to help you go faster and stay stronger for longer.

​

Now, for the sports science purists among you, the 'Tabata' intervals should actually be named 'Koichi' intervals, since it was Japanese speedskating coach Irisawa Koichi who first employed the use of the 20-seconds on / 10-seconds off intervals that Dr. Izumi then confirmed via physiology lab studies to yield the best mix of maximal aerobic and anaerobic stress among the different on/off protocols that he tested.

​

For this workout, we have toned down the original intensity of the Tabata intervals to target MAP rather than Anaerobic Capacity in order to be able to complete the 20/10 micro-intervals and then follow the short efforts immediately with sustained 80-100% of FTP intervals to replicate the kind of attack and then settle efforts that are common in cycling races.

​

From a physiological perspective, you’ll produce lots of lactate during the micro-intervals. Then the goal of the tempo and FTP efforts is to stress your body’s capacity to clear that lactate as quickly as possible. Effectively, we’re trying to maximize lactate 'flux.' For each successive round of the efforts, you’ll do one less micro-interval, and the tempo efforts will get shorter. But because you’re a Sufferlandrian, they won’t get easier, and the rest between sets will get shorter. The intensity for the tempo efforts will ramp up with each repetition. Fortunately for you, there are only 3 sets of efforts and you’ll be done in just 30 minutes. If you’ve set aside an hour for this workout, you’ll be happy to have those additional 30 minutes for recovery after this session.

prospects.name: N. Henderson 2: Rabbit Mountain
prospects.description:
It's your first day joining Neal for a ride, so he's taking you out with a few of his friends -- Jeff, Julie, and Heather -- for a series of four, 10-minute repeats on the infamous Rabbit Mountain. And while the road might repeat, the efforts won't as Neal's come up with a different approach for each one.

​

In between the efforts, you'll learn that Neal is a bit of a collector -- at least when it comes to cycling stuff. He shows you his personal bike collection (he really takes N+1 to the next level), lets you dig around in his wardrobe, and even takes you down to the wine cellar for a look at some pretty special bottles.

​

**When to ride: Do this on day 1 of the 7-day plan.**

​

_About: Neal Henderson is one of the most accomplished coaches in cycling and multi-sport. His athletes have won more than 50 World Championships, set numerous world and national records, captured Olympic medals, worn leaders jerseys, and won stages in races like the Tour de France. Neal, a former professional triathlete, has won numerous Coach of the Year awards throughout his career from organizations like the US Olympic Committee, USA Cycling and USA Triathlon. Watch the Introduction to this series to learn more._

prospects.name: I. Boswell 3: Strength Endurance
prospects.description:
When he's riding inside, Ian's a fan of the Sufferfest workouts Power Station and GOAT. So it's no surprise he's taking you on one of his favorite rides: big gear strength efforts on long climbs in the hills around the farmhouse. Not only that, but he's also going to teach you to cut down a tree and stack firewood! What a day!

​

_Do this on: Day 2 of the 7-day plan._

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Galicia: Corcubión to Fisterra
prospects.description:
Welcome to Corcubión, a gorgeous seaside town in Galicia, Spain. This is where we’ll start our 17k, 38mins ride along the coast while completing some over/unders, tempo and a tough little threshold level finish that’s been used in the Vuelta d’Espana. Along the way, your host, Michael Cotty, will take you through lush forests, over gravel roads and into the history and mythology of this ancient region. Be ready for some wind, some great stories and more than a few incredible views.

​

If you're looking for variety, this workout has got plenty of it and is a lovely little MAP builder as well as a solid session to improve your FTP.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/7402424420)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tour Down Under 1
prospects.description:
**Featured Rider:** Nicole Frain, National Champion of Australia 🥇

**Event:** Santos Tour Down Under Festival of Cycling - Stage 1 🇦🇺

**Mission:** "Finish at the Front": Nicole Frain, newly crowned Australian Road Champion, and her Roxsolt/SRAM team have arrived at the Festival of Cycling in South Australia with the goal of a top overall result and, perhaps, a stage win. The goal on this first stage from Tanunda to Williamstown is to make a mark on the race and, ideally, get on the podium. You’ll join the race with 58 kilometers to go and experience all the thrilling action exactly as Nicole did – but relative to your own fitness level.

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tasmania: Cygnet Coast Road
prospects.description:
The setting might be one of stunning tranquility, but this workout certainly isn't. We're down in far, far Southern Tasmania for a ride along one of the most stunning - but little known - roads in the region. Starting in the hamlet of Cradoc, we head south along the peninsula to the village of Cygnet. It's a rolling road with countless little 'kickers' that we're going to hit at maximum intensity in order to simulate a race or hard group ride. Along the way, we'll pop in to visit some of the most interesting characters who call this area home: a winemaker, an artist, and the founder of a famous cooking school.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2927502558987635926)

​

_About your host: Who better to show you around Tasmania than Nicole Frain? Raised in the north of the island, and currently living just outside Hobart, Nicole knows all the best places to spend your time on and off the bike. Known for her aggressive racing, the Parkhotel-Valkenberg professional won the 2022 Australian Elite Road Race Championship with a late attack and also finished second overall at the 2022 Tour Down Under. Good luck staying with her as she takes you through these workouts!_

​

Featured in this video:

[Farmhouse Kitchen](https://www.thefarmhousekitchen-tas.com/)

[Sailor Seeks Horse](https://sailorseekshorse.com.au/)

[Matt Calvert](https://mattcalvert.com.au/)

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Blender (Mini Version)
prospects.description: _Mini Blender_ takes all the best parts of the SUF classic _Blender_ and condenses them into a workout that's less than 60-minutes long. The sustained efforts at the start ensure your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) are really put to the test during the two sets of micro-intervals (the dreaded "Pain Shakes"). Just like the regular _Blender_, throwing some shorter threshold efforts your way after those AC and MAP builders means that your FTP doesn’t get left out. A perfect session for those who want to hit lots of improvement areas within an hour.

prospects.name: Running With Wolves
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): Cyclingnews Films were granted access to Quick-Step Floors, a team that calls themselves 'The Wolfpack', to follow riders and staff throughout the three weeks of the Tour, with interviews and behind the scenes footage as the team battled it out in the biggest and toughest sporting event on the planet.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Made This
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024): In professional bike racing, we don't often see the whole picture. We only see the starts and the finishes, the breakaways and crashes, the near misses and podiums. Made This presented by Wahoo + MAAP is a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with women's pro cycling team Lifeplus - Wahoo:

1. **Sisterhood: **Dedication, challenges, commitment, belief, family and sisterhood are all components of what it takes to be a professional racing team. In the first of a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with team Lifeplus-Wahoo, MADE THIS is a collection of short films from MAAP Pro Team Racing that reveals what it takes to make a champion a champion.
2. **Prepared for anything: **The excitement of Holy Week at the Tour de Flanders is upon us, and Team Lifeplus-Wahoo is gearing up for a challenging ride. With 163km to conquer, featuring 12 climbs and seven cobbled stretches, not to mention seven slippery flat stone sections—all under a deluge of rain—anything could happen.
3. **Passion on the cobbles: **Join us as we dive deep into the chaotic and exhilarating world of the Paris-Roubaix, one of cycling's most grueling races. Amidst the cobblestones and mud, Team Lifeplus-Wahoo faces the ultimate test of endurance and skill. With a new lineup and high stakes, the team navigates the unpredictable nature of this legendary race, where luck can play a huge role and every second counts.
4. **Home sweet home: **After a fallow year for the tour, the team are eager to push for results in front of an expectant crowd. But instead of the warm welcome on familiar roads, disaster strikes the first morning of the race. As national news of the unfortunate event breaks, the team are left wondering if they'll be able to compete or if this becomes a home visit to forget. What follows is a true act of human kindness and a gesture that symbolises the unifying bond of the women's pro peloton.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Open: 30
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session features footage from the Col Collective.

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 3 Pt 3
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023):

**Episode 4: Finding Balance**

We follow Megan Mouser and her journey from 3 years of FTGU. Megan is an incredible mom, self described as "Workin' on body positivity 1 mile at a time and the epitome of our community at From the Ground Up. We are so excited to finally share her story up to race day!

​

**Episode 5: Rookies Again**

What does it take for ex-NFL athletes to redefine a healthy lifestyle and take on something as foreign as riding a mountain

bike? Kawika and Amani took a leap this year, and are working to inspire and motivate other athletes post career. In this episode we look at Kawika and Amani's backgrounds and watch them learn to ride a MTB comfortably as they step onto a whole new type of playing field.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Cadence Drills (Builds/Holds/Single Leg)
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

The last drill, Single Leg Efforts, ask you to unclip one leg and ride at a steady, single-legged effort. This forces you to pull up on the pedal instead of just pushing down and ensures maximal muscle awareness and engagement. This workout is best done while riding indoors on a trainer because even small variations in terrain can affect your ability to properly execute this workout. The majority of this workout is done in heart rate Z1/2 /// 50-75% of threshold /// RPE 2-5. You should keep the effort level below threshold (heart rate Z4, 100% of threshold, RPE 7-8) during the max cadence efforts.

​

WORKOUT GOALS:

- To improve stillness and stability at high cadences.
- To improve muscle fiber engagement for improved efficiency at all cadences.
- To increase maximum cadence.
- To make that pedal stroke as smooth as butter.

CADENCE TARGETS:

- Warm-up 80-90rpm
- Build: 90-150rpm
- Hold: 115rpm
- Single Leg: 85rpm

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

​

**Warm Up**

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70%

3 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 3

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 23 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Cadence Build: 30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- Starting at 90RPM Build to Max RPM -- Max Power is NOT Goal

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Cadence Hold: 45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- <100% FTP -- Highest RPM you can hold without Bouncing

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only -- <50% of FTP

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only, Opposite Leg -- <50% of FTP (100% of FTP with both legs = 50% of FTP

with one leg)

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: AC: 2 Sets 5 x 30
prospects.description:
If you're short time, but looking for a good AC hit, then look no further. This 28-minute long session includes 2 sets of five repeats of 30 seconds of AC effort with just 60 seconds recovery between efforts. This is a heavy duty session, so bring your A-game...or maybe make that your best AC game!

​

**Warm Up**

3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP-- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 1 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 5

Rest between sets: 5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: 5

**Interval**

Work: 30 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 100% of MAP -- HR >105%

Rest:

30 seconds @ RPE 1 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

3 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Lake Chira
prospects.description:
Our first ever On Location gravel adventure and what a ride we have in store! This one may be short but it’ll have you hanging onto the edge of your saddle as we explore the Pilancones Natural Park, high up on a mountain ridge overlooking the Soria valley as we head towards Chira Lake. The goal of this ride will be to work on your good form with a slightly higher cadence than normal, keeping the legs supple and spinning. We’ll gently build the effort up a 3km climb to get the heart, legs and lungs working a little harder before descending to our final destination at Chira Lake. This workout is perfect for those days when you need an easier session or want to activate the body before going deeper.

​

This workout focusses on a progressive build through the duration of the climb helping with your pacing skills and sustained efforts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8773915186)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: G.O.A.T.
prospects.description:
This session is all about high-torque efforts, very similar to the efforts you would experience riding up the steep slopes of Mt Sufferlandria. While these efforts are short and the intensity isn’t too high, the low cadence targets combined with minimal recovery will leave some begging for the high-cadence sprints of _The Omnium_. High-torque efforts like these have two primary benefits: improved neuromuscular coordination and increased muscular endurance.

​

During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. High-cadence efforts in something like _Cadence Builds_ are great for teaching these groups to make that switch quickly. These low-cadence efforts are better for teaching ALL of the muscles in your legs to “switch on.” Done properly, you should be pulling with your hamstrings with one leg while the other leg is pushing down with all the force your glutes and quads can muster. If you feel like you are pushing yourself up out of the saddle during harder efforts (like seated sprints), your hamstrings are not being utilized since they should pull you back down into your saddle.

​

The second main benefit is improved muscular endurance. Even though the session is under 45 minutes, **you'll put a similar amount of muscular fatigue into your legs as a steady, multi-hour base ride.** You can almost view this session as hitting the leg press for 8 sets of 100 reps. And just like the weight room, proper form is absolutely key. That means:

- You should focus on pushing down AND pulling back up. You want your glutes and quads activated on the way down and your hamstring and hip flexors activated on the way up.
- To properly engage your hamstrings think about trying to pulling your heel up to your butt when your crank arm is going from 6 o’clock to 10 o’clock.
- Your knees should be tracking straight up and down, no collapsing in or out.
- Your core should be fully engaged to keep your hips steady in the saddle. This will be easier if you are both pushing and pulling during each pedal revolution.

This session is very similar to _Power Station_. Both help improve your muscular endurance and coordination; the biggest difference is the work to rest ratio between the two. While the intervals here are shorter than those in _Power Station_, the decreased recovery duration means fatigue will build faster, especially for those with a weakness in repeated efforts.

Modifying interval length and recovery duration can also be seen between sessions like _Revolver_ and _A Very Dark Place_. Both serve up a healthy dose of MAP/VO2 work, but the overall feeling of those two sessions is different.

If you find that your lower back starts to ache during this session or that you have to start rocking in the saddle to keep the power up, then it’s time for you to get started on the SYSTM Yoga program. Kick it off with “Core Strengtheners ” to make sure your core is just as strong as those legs.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[When to Train with Low Cadence](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/when-to-train-with-low-cadence)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: The Way Out
prospects.description:
One of the few Sufferfest sessions that can be viewed as a sweet-spot session since the intervals aren’t above threshold (except for the very end) but are harder than a tempo effort.

​

This session pushes your body close to the limit of what it can comfortably handle without going any further. Why? Going above threshold causes a considerable amount of hormonal stress that takes a lot of time to recover from. But you don’t actually have to ride above threshold to improve your FTP. The difference in fitness gains between 30 minutes at 90% of threshold and at 102% of threshold is minimal. Still, the stress on your body from the latter is much greater, and the recovery much longer.

​

That's why this session is a key component to any training plan: It gives you enough training stress to help improve your FTP but remains 'easy' enough that you can do it when you're tired or before a big block of harder efforts.

prospects.name: Tour of Norway 2
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Carl Fredrick HAGEN of Norway

**Event: **Tour of Norway

**Mission - "Wonderkid":** Experience the thrill of the breakaway with the peloton breathing down your neck - You're riding for Team Lotto Soudal - You've been in the breakaway all day. There's just one hour of racing left and you're sitting at the top of the virtual GC on the last day of the Tour of Norway, your home tour — Of any day to go all out and empty the tank, today is the day — Take your pulls, lead the breakaway and fight to stay away from the peloton.

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: P. Gaimon 3: Short KOM Training Session
prospects.description:
As part of his ‘Worst Retirement Ever,’ Phil made a name for himself by sniping Strava KOMs around the world. But if you’re going to travel around globe stealing crowns from some of the world’s fastest climbers, you need to bring your A-game.

​

In this short, 35-minute workout, Phil takes you through a warm-up on the famous Pacific Coast Highway before climbing into two short, maximal efforts on the way up Dekker Canyon. You’ll be in the hurt box, but be sure to pay attention as Phil drops his top tips for KOM / QOM segment success.

​

In between efforts, Phil keeps you entertained with stories about his Cookie Fondo, life in LA, a tour of his garage, a face lick from his dog and his personal recommendation for the best cold-pressed juice in town.

​

_Do this on: Day 3 of the 5-day plan._

prospects.name: AC: 6 x 45s
prospects.description:
There's no getting around the fact that this is a profoundly unpleasant session that will leave your legs feeling like jelly. This session is similar to The Trick, with a few differences. On the plus side, all of the efforts are 15-seconds shorter than those in The Trick. To make up for this, we added two more intervals to this session, bringing the total to 6. That means by the end of this session you will have plowed through 4.5-minutes of AC work.

This workout is one of the few sessions that we do NOT recommend you complete in ERG mode if you are on a smart trainer. The goal is to hold onto the highest power you can for the full 45-seconds. Inevitably in the later sets, your power will dip before you reach the end of the interval. What we want is for you to complete every effort having given everything for 45-seconds. We don't want ERG mode grinding you to a halt because you cannot maintain the (ridiculously) high power targets. Even if you drop down below FTP in the final 10-seconds of these efforts, as long as you are going flat out, you are doing it correctly.

Just take this session one interval at a time, and focus on giving your all for this one effort. You can worry about the others when you get to them. If you finish this session without swearing, then you didn't go hard enough!

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <70

45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <90

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105

45 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- HR >105

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 6

Rest Between Sets: 5 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Effort: 45 seconds @ RPE 9.5 -- 150% of FTP -- HR >105

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

4 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70

prospects.name: The Rookie
prospects.description:
These race simulations steadily get harder and harder as the workout progresses, so don’t be too keen to increase the intensity after the first 10-minute effort if it felt “too easy.” Just wait. The pain will come.

​

During each interval, you'll be ducking and diving right under and over threshold, forcing your body to churn through all the metabolites you're producing (that's the nasty stuff that the Painsuckers love so much). This is one of the best ways to improve your FTP without really overloading your system with too much training stress.

​

The final two intervals allow you to really charge over your threshold to unleash whatever power you have left in your legs. These two all-out bursts of power, in addition to the constant surges above threshold, means this session works your Anaerobic Capacity more than some of the other FTP-focused sessions.

prospects.name: The Omnium
prospects.description:
Do you know what we love about you? Your versatility. You can Suffer anywhere, anytime, and in any way. That's why Grunter von Agony, Sufferlandrian Team Director, is sending you to compete in The Omnium at the UCI World Track Championships. Over the course of 50 minutes, you'll do battle in the six different races.

​

No two intervals in this workout are the same, with each one working slightly different Neuromuscular (NM), Anaerobic Capacity (AC), and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) variations. No need for FTP here, friends. It's the perfect session to improve top-end power without having to do a ton of repetitive efforts.

​

The Scratch Race and Flying Lap have an easy enough lead-in that you get to put your max sprint to the full test. Add in the standing starts for the Individual Pursuit and Kilo, and you give your NM a real run-through. The repeated surges of the Elimination Race, the all-out nature of the Kilo, and the massive efforts you have to make in the points race really test your powers of recovery while working your AC all the way to the max.

​

Since the efforts come in quick succession, and with most being over four minutes in length, your cardiovascular system never catches a real break, ensuring your MAP doesn’t get left out of the equation.

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: Attacker
prospects.description:
Being able to finish strong comes from properly pacing your efforts and preparing to finish strong. This session is all about improving those abilities. For just over 50 minutes, you'll tackle five different 6-minute long, progressive efforts that start just below FTP and finish well above it for the final minute.

​

The real challenge of this workout is the limited 1-minute recovery sections between each effort. You’ll want to savor every second of those short recoveries. This workout will help improve your FTP and improve your ability to recover while pushing just under your threshold for the first half of each effort. You’ll also learn to manage your pacing and put out power above your threshold after holding steady just below that breakpoint.

​

Riders with sustained weakness will benefit greatly from this workout, as will anyone looking to push up their FTP.

_Attacker_ is quite similar to the SUF workout, _Defender._ However, the efforts within each interval are 2-minutes shorter, and instead of starting harder and backing off like in _Defender,_ the efforts in this session start controlled and keep squeezing harder and harder until the end.

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Galicia: Camarinas to Muxia
prospects.description:
It’s time for a wild coastal adventure with your host, Michael Cotty, across some of the stunning undulating roads of Galica, Spain. You’ll start at a historic lighthouse on the ‘Coast of Death’ before working your way deep into the rugged landscape that defines this region. The road will guide your workout, with big efforts up every hill and a chance to take it a bit easier on the descents. It’s not all hard work, though, Mike takes the time to show you around the fishing marina, where to find the ‘hunger herb’ and some of the sights around our finishing village, Muxia.

​

This is a great session for anyone who wants to get in a bit of sprint/anaerobic capacity efforts while laying down some solid aerobic time.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/7392408454)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Laps Tasmania
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2019): Following Dustin Hollick and Rhian Slapp, two ordinary fathers with the survival skills of well-trained house pets, on a two-week journey around Tasmania with not much more than the clothes on their backs. No cash, no car, and no technology on an island at the bottom of the world.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: Found in America
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): After finishing the Race Across America on the podium, Dave Haase is coming back to win it. But is that what he's really looking for? Is there more to why he's taking on such a formidable challenge than the pursuit of victory alone? This is an honest look at the demands of a legendary ultra-endurance race and what one finds out on the road.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Cadence Drills (Builds/Holds/Single Leg)
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

The last drill, Single Leg Efforts, ask you to unclip one leg and ride at a steady, single-legged effort. This forces you to pull up on the pedal instead of just pushing down and ensures maximal muscle awareness and engagement. This workout is best done while riding indoors on a trainer because even small variations in terrain can affect your ability to properly execute this workout. The majority of this workout is done in heart rate Z1/2 /// 50-75% of threshold /// RPE 2-5. You should keep the effort level below threshold (heart rate Z4, 100% of threshold, RPE 7-8) during the max cadence efforts.

​

WORKOUT GOALS:

- To improve stillness and stability at high cadences.
- To improve muscle fiber engagement for improved efficiency at all cadences.
- To increase maximum cadence.
- To make that pedal stroke as smooth as butter.

CADENCE TARGETS:

- Warm-up 80-90rpm
- Build: 90-150rpm
- Hold: 115rpm
- Single Leg: 85rpm

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

​

**Warm Up**

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70%

3 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 3

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 23 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Cadence Build: 30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- Starting at 90RPM Build to Max RPM -- Max Power is NOT Goal

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Cadence Hold: 45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- <100% FTP -- Highest RPM you can hold without Bouncing

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only -- <50% of FTP

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only, Opposite Leg -- <50% of FTP (100% of FTP with both legs = 50% of FTP

with one leg)

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Open: 40
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the Road Race of The Hammer Series.

prospects.name: Nine Hammers
prospects.description:
Sometimes you're the hammer. Sometimes you're the nail. And sometimes, you're getting both hammered and nailed. With a series of nine different intervals, all at or above threshold, this is one of the best Maximal Aerobic Power / VO2 sessions in The Sufferfest library. It isn’t just the total amount of time spent above threshold, though.

​

This workout takes the training stress up a notch by giving you barely enough time to recover from the previous hammer before the next one falls. This ensures your Anaerobic Capacity gets a little boost as well.

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: London-Edinburgh-London
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2016): London Edinburgh London follows a group of cyclists from around the world on a remarkable feat of endurance. Join their ride up the length of Britain - from London to Edinburgh and back again - in under five days. Traveling over 1400km, a continuous distance far further than most of them had ever ridden before, our unlikely and eccentric heroes are not only tested physically but face the mental challenge, "can I push myself further? Can I go one more day?".

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: The Frozen Road
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2017): From the creator: "Self-shot and edited whilst cycling around the world, this film charts a winter journey into the Canadian Arctic as I completed my bike ride up the American continent. Compelled by Jack London’s assertion, that ‘any man who is a man can travel alone,' I sought an adventure of perfect solitude. Yet, as I came to realize, the harsh truths of traveling in such a formidable environment were a long way from the romantic images I’d held of this land. _The Frozen Road_’ is an honest reflection on my solo trip; of the wonder, terror and frustration I experienced when riding through the unforgiving emptiness of one of the world’s ‘last great wildernesses."

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Half Is Easy
prospects.description:
For too long, perhaps, we have shrugged off questions about whether The Sufferfest workouts were too hard as Couchlandrians attempted to sway public opinion toward a life devoid of HONOR, GLORY, and VICTORY. But it's gone on too long and we had to respond. So, over a bottle of Real Pagne, legendary Directeur Sportif Grunter von Agony had a quiet word with a man named Ian Field. You may know that Ian is an elite coach with Dig Deep Coaching and a four-time British National Cyclocross National Champion. After an evil laugh that lingered, he provided us with a workout he uses to perform at the highest levels of the Cyclocross World Cup. 'Don't worry,' said Ian. 'The Couchlandrians will enjoy half of it.'

​

This is a fantastic session for improving Anaerobic Capacity (AC). The short, high-intensity efforts with equally short recoveries stress your body's ability to recover quickly. In fact, the recoveries are short enough that you never really get a “full recovery” during a set. This means your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) is developed in the latter half of both sets as fatigue sets in. It's also worth mentioning that because of the short durations, you do tap into your Neuromuscular Power (NM) at the start of each effort.

prospects.name: Provence: Gorges de la Nesque
prospects.description:
We're in Provence, France for a stunning 24k ride - and workout - along the Gorges de la Nesque. As you learn all about the local lavender, craft beer, how to make nougat, and why there are all those holes in the ground, Mike will take you through a series of sub-threshold cadence changes and big sprints before cooling down on the run-in to Monieux.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3930255146)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Wahoo Frontiers 2020
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): 2020 was one heck of a year. We released several episodes about Wahoo athletes pushing themselves and those around them into new frontiers. Here, we compile those videos for your viewing pleasure -- from the transformation and triumph of Ian Boswell to the downhill determination of Tahnée Seagrave and several stories in-between, there's something here to inspire everyone.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Violator
prospects.description:
If your Neuromuscular Power (NM) and Anaerobic Capacity (AC) got together to throw a party and everybody left that party shattered but better off for it, then this would be it. _Violator_ is the perfect example of how the amount of recovery time between efforts dramatically changes the amount—and type—of training stress you get.

​

Yes, there are 64 sprints, but they're not all doing the same thing for your fitness. The first set of sprints has enough recovery that you'll be able to work your NM to the max. The second set still has enough recovery to allow you to hit high power numbers, but the reduced time between sprints stresses your ability to recover and repeat that high effort. That means you'll start to dip into AC. The last set—with equal sprint and recovery times—ensures your heart rate never gets a chance to drop down. That works your MAP like nobody's business.
prospects.notes:
You should remain seated for all of these sprint efforts (and in the drops if that is where you spend most of your time during racing)

This means you need to ignore the power targets, your only goal is to give a maximal seated effort each and every sprint. 

This means you will likely be under target power in the first set, and maybe over power targets in the final set, that does not matter. You are just looking to go all out 64 times!

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Fight Club
prospects.description:
A full remastering of one of our earliest sessions (the original is still available to those of you who are Knights of Sufferlandria), Fight Club is scrappy, messy, and unpredictable. Like a real bike race, you're working hard to stay with the leaders while fending off attacks and doing your best to make the race by attacking as well.

​

With significant time spent at power well above your threshold, this is a solid session to improve your Anaerobic Capacity. The fact that all those surges take place during sustained efforts right around threshold makes this one of the most difficult (yet beneficial) workouts in The Sufferfest Library. Repeated surges followed by sustained riding near your threshold stress your body's ability to clear metabolites (like lactate) and your mental ability to “deal” with the extreme discomfort all those metabolites cause. You're going to come out of this one a bit battered but a lot stronger for it.

prospects.name: Cash Register
prospects.description:
Over/under intervals, where you alternate going just below and just above threshold, are the foundation of many classic workouts. Cash Register is an adaptation of that idea and comes in the format of a sprint/settle/surge session consisting of 4 intervals that get a little shorter (but not easier) each round.

​

Each interval kicks off with a sprint effort that targets your Neuromuscular (NM) power. Then you settle into a controlled, below-FTP effort that will accelerate the rate at which you can clear lactate from your muscles. You'll finish each effort off with a big surge based on your Anaerobic Capacity (AC). In just 30 minutes, you'll be doing efforts targeting your sprint power, FTP, and AC for an exceptionally well-rounded workout.

​

Support the Wahooligan Tour by [donating to the Davis Phinney Foundation](https://secure2.convio.net/dpf/site/TR?pg=pfind&fr_id=1391) and their programs to help people living with Parkinsons.

prospects.name: MAP: 3 x 2
prospects.description:
The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near your VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of each interval, especially in the final few intervals.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be tapping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. To account for this, we have limited the recovery duration to be equal to the interval duration. Limited recovery ensures that you will drain your Anaerobic Capacity before the end of the intervals, meaning your body will be forced to produce as much power as possible using oxygen.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

7 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

2 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

3 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: N/A

Interval Repeats Per Set: 3

**Interval**

Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 95-105% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Recovery: 6 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes @ RPE 1 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Into the Rift
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: To simply finish the Atlas Mountain Race means navigating 1,200 kilometres of the most rugged and remote roads in Morocco. To win requires riding almost non-stop, night and day, for days on end. It's a combination of strength and sleep deprivation that only a few riders in the world can manage. Alone, unsupported and loaded down with supplies, each competitor must constantly battle mechanicals, heat exhaustion and saddle sores to get to the finish. There is no prize, no money, simply the satisfaction that comes from pushing oneself to the limit while exploring the forgotten corners of a beautiful country. With support from PEdALED, Canyon, Fizik and the race crew led by organiser and route creator Nelson Trees, filmmaker Brady Lawrence followed the race documenting everything from a brutal 80 kilometre walk through the high desert with a broken bike, to one racer’s simple joy at realising they’ll soon eat their first warm meal in days. Featuring the sport’s biggest names and first-time, ultra- distance racers alike, the film gets up close to the kind of people crazy enough to take on this epic challenge. Capturing the human drama set against an otherworldly landscape, Into the Rift is an in-depth look at a true cycling adventure.

​

🚴Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

​

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

- Triceps Push-Ups

prospects.description:

It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I

The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.
